intro: Hyssopus officinalis f. ruber, commonly known as the red hyssop, is a cultivar of the hyssop plant characterized by its distinctive reddish-purple flower spikes. It is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region and belongs to the Lamiaceae family, known for its aromatic and medicinal properties. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring narrow, gray-green leaves and showy, tubular flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It is often used in gardens for its ornamental value and has historical uses in herbal medicine for its antiseptic and expectorant qualities.
